title: Tips for Talking About Food Allergies

content: Sharing information about your food allergy can be met with a wide array of responses. I’ve received everything from sympathy to complete disregard to rare and oh-so-welcomed support. With my combined personal experience as a food allergy mom and my professional background in public relations and corporate communications, I’m both acutely aware of the nuances of messaging and deeply mindful of the impact our words have on others.

If you are reading this, I’m betting you are a food allergy parent yourself and you are in the trenches with me. Thank you for being here. I am writing this to commiserate with you, and I hope this helps you feel seen.

However, this is also for the teacher, caregiver, family member, friend, or other person in your life who really does not get what you go through on a daily basis. I hope you can share this article with the important people in your life whose understanding you need to keep your children safe. My goal is to offer a viewpoint into our world to those who don’t live this every day. I hope the information I’m about to share creates the opportunity for productive conversations.

content: Let’s get to it! First, I’m going to share the top six things to NOT say to a food allergy parent, including a note as to why these comments are not useful or can be hurtful. Then, we’ll get to the good stuff – the BEST three statements to say to a food allergy parent to show your support.
What NOT to say to a food allergy parent:
“I don’t know how you do it. I could never deal with food allergies!”

Yes, yes, you could. If your child was allergic to a food, or multiple foods, of course you would figure it out just as all of us food allergy parents have. You would cook around the allergen(s), scour ingredients lists, advocate for your child, etc., in all the ways that we do. Saying something along these lines has an underlying notion that food allergy is somehow a choice. It is not.

sections.heading: “Wait, your child is allergic to (insert list)?! What do you feed him?!”

content: We feed him everything else, thank you. There is a great big world of food outside of peanuts, dairy, wheat, egg, and some of the other most common foods in our diets. In fact, I’d argue that our diets are better without ultra-processed foods that we should not eat, anyway. (I’m looking at you, gluten and dairy.) Yes, it is challenging to not be able to rely on common and available foods, and you have no idea how hard it is to strictly avoid them, but we do it! And truly, we are healthier for it. The implication of a statement like this is that food allergies make our family abnormal or difficult, and that’s simply not true.
“Can’t you just relax about this?”

No, no, no. I cannot. When your child has a diagnosed IgE-mediated food allergy, it is potentially life-threatening. Read that again: life-threatening. For those of us who have seen our children have an anaphylactic reaction to a food (for some of us, multiple times) we know what damage these allergens can do to our children. We live all day every day with the feeling of our kids playing on the side of a busy highway, just one tiny step away from catastrophe. We manage the absolute best we can with education, advocacy, and all kinds of safeguards. It becomes ingrained into our lives, and we manage around it. But no, we cannot just relax. A sentence along these lines is dismissive of the severity of this disease and has no place in any conversation with a food allergy parent.

sections.heading: “Couldn’t she have just a little bit?”
content: Nope! Not even a little bit. With food allergy, even the tiniest speck can cause a severe reaction. There are no “mild allergies,” just mild reactions. And to make things even more complicated, how your child reacted once does not dictate a future reaction. There are many components that go into what causes anaphylaxis, and quantity of the allergen consumed is just one part of it. Anyone with a food allergy must strictly avoid that allergen all the time. Period. Asking a question like this is just another way of undermining the gravity of food allergies.

sections.heading: “Did you breastfeed?” OR “Did you eat peanuts (or other allergens) while pregnant?” OR “Did you have a C-section?”
content: Please don’t go down this road of “did you” or “didn’t you” to a food allergy parent. I can personally attest to doing everything “right,” and my kids both have multiple, severe food allergies. Research on pregnancy and infancy recommendations is constantly evolving, and the guidance of what is “right” to do has changed over the years. Regardless of what you ate during pregnancy, how you delivered, and if you breastfed or not, food allergies are steeply on the rise for a wide variety of reasons. We don’t have all the answers yet! In the meantime, any messaging like this is deeply hurtful to a food allergy mom because it insinuates that it is somehow our fault. Please don’t ask, even if you’re simply curious.

sections.heading: “I feel so bad for you.” OR “I feel so bad for your child.”
content: This one is a hard pass. Do not say anything like this to someone who is managing food allergies (themselves or their children). A statement like this might honestly be said with good intentions, but none of us wants or needs sympathy. Food allergies are a PART of our lives, NOT our whole lives. And it certainly doesn’t define who we or our children are. If I were to tell you about my two boys, I would list all kinds of awesome things about their personalities, their interests, and their talents. I honestly wouldn’t even mention food allergies unless it was information you needed to know. Or I would use it as an example of their resilience and grit. But most of us never lead with it. Food allergies don’t dictate our life, and we don’t need your pity.

Phew! That all felt really good to release! But, as always, my goal is always to educate and empower with positivity. Let’s pivot this conversation to the top three things you should say to someone managing food allergies.

sections.heading: What TO say to a food allergy parent:
content: “I know you are managing a lot. I am here for you.”

These simple two sentences could be used in a lot of scenarios to let anyone know that you see them and care about them. At the end of the day, isn’t that the majority of what we want from our relationships, anyway? We do not expect everyone to be an expert on food allergies. We do not expect anyone to completely change their home or their routine for our health needs. But living with food allergies actually is a lot to handle. And just being acknowledged, validated, and supported is incredibly appreciated.
“I want you and/or your child to feel safe and included.”

Food allergy parents don’t assume you automatically know how to make our children feel safe and included, but we would be eternally grateful if you’d tell us you’d like to do so (and then follow through). In reality, it is usually simpler than most people think. Creating a safe environment for our food allergy children can be as easy as a playdate with no food, or asking people to wash their hands before hanging out, or being prepared with a pre-approved safe treat for an event. “Safe and included” is the phrase I have used most when discussing my boys, particularly with their teachers. Usually, a couple of small behavior changes that have minimal implications for the broader group can go a long way and make a significant difference for our family. It starts with communicating the desire to want to make a classroom, home, or situation safe, and that is the best intention ever.

sections.heading: “I’d like to learn more about food allergies. Where can I find accurate information?”
content: When you are a food allergy parent, you are educating and advocating all the time. All. The. Time. We gladly do it because every extra person who understands food allergies makes the world a little safer for our kiddos. Some of us (hi, me!) even choose to also do this professionally and wouldn’t have it any other way. But, in reality, sometimes we are tired. Straight up exhausted, actually. If you’d like to take that extra step and show true love to the food allergy parent in your life, ask us where you can go on your own to study the food allergy landscape in order to be a better friend, caregiver, or family member. I always direct people to the Food Allergy Research & Education (FARE) website, which has a plethora of accurate, easy-to-understand food allergy data and information. Even taking a small amount of time to educate yourself on food allergies will go such a long way to show those who manage this disease that you care.

sections.heading: Please remember…
content: I believe that most of the inaccurate, unkind, or flippant remarks I’ve heard regarding food allergies are due way more to a lack of education than a lack of caring. As I’ve outlined here, there are unfortunately more hurtful responses than helpful ones. I hope that by transparently sharing what is positive versus what is negative, and how these words impact someone managing food allergies, we can all do a better job communicating with each other. After all, discussing food allergies isn’t all that different from conversations about anything important in our lives. We don’t want to be dismissed, blamed, or belittled. And we do want to be seen, validated, and supported. We really are all in this together, so let’s choose our words wisely and show each other some love.
